moves.1. e4: This is an interesting game of attrition where there were ebs and flows with the momentum shifting one way then the other before the game came to its natural conclusion. For much of the end-game it looked like a draw when Black made a critical mistake that decided the game.
moves.1... e5: the opening was fairly typical with each of us jockying for control of the board as the opening developed
moves.2. d4: I offered the Queens pawn in an exchange
moves.2... Nf6: but the offer was declined forcing me to defend the Kings pawn
moves.3. Nc3: This presented black with a  chance to pin the Knight against the King
moves.4... Bxc3+: black forced the exchange which is fine with me since I like my Bishops for later in the game and don't mind surrendering a Knight for a Bishop exchange
moves.5. bxc3: The problem this presents for me is the double pawn in the C rank
moves.5... exd4: But black gave me an immediate opportunity to solve that problem
moves.6. Qxd4: But I decline the offer choosing instead to bring my Queen into the game.
moves.6... O-O: causing black to resort to Castling, a good defensive manouver under the circumstances
moves.7. e5: but it allows me to advance my Pawn into black territory and threaten the Knight
moves.7... Re8: Moving the Castle to the open rank is a good move, and I am prevented from capturing his Knight by the check that would result.
moves.8. Nf3: So I continue my development toward Castling
moves.8... d6: this presents a situation where a Queen exchange might be in the offing
moves.9. Bf4: But I am also able to advance my development by bringing my black Bishop into the game
moves.10. Nxe5: But a pawn will never overcome a well positioned Queen protected by her Knight! And still the Queen exchange looms
moves.10... Nc6: The game is starting to open up now and this Knight attack returns balance to the board, even though I think I still have the advantage by being on the front foot and challenging more of the black side of the board.
moves.11. Qxd8: Believing that I have the tactical advantage, I push forward and exchange Queens
moves.11... Rxd8: This position increases black strength though with the Castle controlling the center rank
moves.12. g3: So I get ready to castle
moves.12... Ne4: Seeing the potential of my retreat, the black Knight comes riding in to cut me off
moves.13... Nc3: and the Knight jumps in to give the Castle cover in a planned long range attack
moves.14. Bd3: So I protect the king with my Bishop preventing the Castle from advancing too far and still allowing me to castle
moves.14... Bh3: With this move, my King is penned in and can pretty much only move freely on the e rank. Should black be able to threaten me on the e rank, I am in trouble
moves.15. a4: So with an attack is arriving in the middle of the board, I attack on the flank to draw the army away
moves.15... Nb4: I am not sure I have achieved my desired result, and with this move, my bishop is under double threat
moves.16. Ra3: I continue to press on the flank to keep black's attention away from my threatened King
moves.16... Nba2: By moving thus, the knights are pinned themselves unless they can escape by threatening another piece
moves.17. Kd2: I take the opportunity to move my King into the attack
moves.17... Ne4+: unfortunately giving his Knight just the opportunity I describe where  check prevents me from capturing the now abandoned Knight
moves.18. Ke3: So I press on with the King forcing the attack. This is unusual for me, but without Queens on the board, and with his black Bishop captured, the King has more freedom over the board during the middle game
moves.18... Nac3: Again the Knights protect each other once again. But the board has changed in character now, and although black has several minor pieces in my half of the board, I am still in good position, and neither player is seriously at a disadvantage.
moves.19. f3: But a Knight guarded by a Knight is no match for a free Pawn with capture on his mind
moves.19... Nc5: And by running away, black has chosen which Knight to sacrifice
moves.20. Rxc3: which my castle captures dutifully putting me ahead with several points for a time.
moves.20... Nxa4: with this move, the deficit is reduced, and my Castle is threatened.
moves.21. Rb3: so I position my Castle to capture the knight should he move it toward my King
moves.21... Nc5: but he runs away allowing me to consolidate my position
moves.23. Bf1: So I threaten the Bishop to force his retreat...
moves.23... a6: But black challenges my Castle instead forcing me to retreat
moves.24... Bf5: and then, so does he, but he puts my pawn in danger by pinning him against my Castle
moves.25. Rc1: so I cover him and remove the danger for the time being
moves.25... Ne6: Black retreats to regroup for his next attack
moves.26. Nc6: so I threaten the Castle with an obvious move
moves.26... Rde8: Which forces the Castle off the open rank
moves.27. Ne5: So I retreat - job done - to protect the open Pawn
moves.28. Nd3: causing me to take up a more defensive posture. I am clearly under pressure and on the back foot now with my Bishop threatened by the Knight and a revealed check
moves.28... Nc5+: Instead, the Knight threatens my Knight leaving me in check from the Castle, so
moves.29... Ne6: and the Knight retreats avoiding the exchange. I remain 2 points ahead after the skirmish
moves.30. Re1: I use the opportunity cover the open rank essentially pinning the Knight against the Castle
moves.30... Nd4: The Knight moves down opening the Castle exchange which
moves.31. Rxe8+: I take advantage of...Hey, I have a two point lead!
moves.31... Rxe8: the exchange complete, I have to regroup...so I
moves.32. Bg2: Open up my Castle so that the first row is protected by him as I anticipate the coming attack.
moves.32... c5: Black pushes his pawns to protect the Knight
moves.34. Kxe1: I use my King to take the Castle rather than my Knight to protect a Pawn, but do not realize the danger I put myself in as a result
moves.34... Nxc2+: The Knight check captures a pawn. So I lose a Pawn and the game is closer after the mistake
moves.35. Kd2: So with my Pawn gone I have to protect my Knight. I am still playing on the back foot.
moves.36... Nb3+: Black continues to attack my King. This check presents no significant danger for me.
moves.37. Kc3: By responding with my King, I force the knight to move away to survive and fight another day.
moves.37... Nd4: Which the Knight does, moving to a position where a check will follow.
moves.38. f4: I decide to develop my Pawn structure
moves.39. Bd5+: I see an interesting opening that I take with a check
moves.39... Be6: Black defends inviting the Bishop exchange.
moves.40. Bxe6+: which I accept in part because it forces the Knight to retreat.
moves.40... Nxe6: I am one point ahead and if we exchange all our pieces, assuming I don't make too many mistakes, I should be in position to win
moves.41. f5: SO I press ahead with my pawn to try to prevent the King from escaping.
moves.41... Nd4: I have to find a way to capture the Knight
moves.42... b5: Black does the same. This is an interesting position where a Pawn exchange will result in check unless I can capture the unprotected pawn first...
moves.43. Nxc5: thus, allowing me to potentially capture two pawns at once.
moves.43... Ne2+: Black forces check, and positions himself to capture my pawns
moves.44. Kd3: so I attack with my King
moves.44... Nc1+: I find myself having to maneuver to bring the Knight under closer scrutiny.
moves.45. Kc2: this creates a need for black to move the Knight once again
moves.45... Ne2: By moving the Knight here, I have access to a pawn
moves.46. cxb5: so now I am two points ahead - the forced exchange strategy is on!
moves.46... Nd4+: The check ensures that blacks captures a pawn in return and threatens my Bishop at the same time
moves.47. Kc3: This is a disastrous move that ensures the loss of my Bishop and a pawn
moves.47... Nxb5+: AAAARCG what a mistake...I should not play chess late at night.
moves.48. Kc4: a futile attempt to chase the Knight down
moves.49. Kb3: so I retreat to prevent the queening of the pawn
moves.49... Kf7: My game is in disarray now and I am a pawn down, and the black King is on the move
moves.50. Ka4: So I see a chance to even the score
moves.50... Nc4: but the black Knight moves to prevent me from doing so
moves.51. Kb5: this move ensures the capture of one or the other
moves.51... Ne3: The Knight moves to stay ahead
moves.52... Ke7: so the King comes to the party essentially surrendering the pawn
moves.53. Kxa5: which puts on on level terms once again.
moves.53... Kd6: Black tries to chase me down with his King
moves.54. Nb7+: but I turn the tables on him by forcing check
moves.54... Ke5: This is a very interesting position. By all accounts, it looks like black has the upper hand
moves.55... Kf4: Black certainly appears to have the upper hand. I have to scramble to stay even.
moves.56. Ne6+: This move puts me a pawn ahead for a time
moves.56... Kg3: what to do...if I capture the pawn, black will capture my pawn and threaten my other pawn
moves.57. Nxg7: but that is really the only move available
moves.57... Kxh3: so now although even, I am about to go a piece down
moves.58. g5: so I force the issue Black can't take both pawns at once
moves.58... Nxf5: I think that this is the mistake of the game. If black had taken my pawn with his pawn, then he would not have sacrificed his Knight.
moves.59. gxf6: but I do not take the knight, instead I take the pawn looking for a queen
moves.59... Nd6: black seeing the danger, tries to retreat to prevent the queening
moves.60. Kb6: My King returns to the battle
moves.60... Kg4: and Black follows suit..who will get there first? Who has the advantage (I think I do because of my board position)
moves.61. Kc6: my King challenges his Knight and he
moves.61... Nf7: retreats to prevent my pawn from advancing
moves.62... Kg5: and the black King does so too
moves.63... Kg6: Black cannot take either piece with his King because my King is too close
moves.64. Ne6: so I decide to sacrifice my Knight to ensure that I queen
moves.64... h5: black starts to advance his pawn
moves.65. Nf4+: and I place him in check also threatening the pawn
moves.65... Kg5: this is the expected move forcing me to make a key decision in the game. If I take the pawn then he will take the Knight and then I can take the Knight in return, and possibly win the game that way by protecting the pawn and queening it. If I take the Knight and sacrifice my Knight, I will get a Queen more quickly and have to scramble to prevent him form queening his pawn..interesting choice...so I choose...
moves.66. Kxf7: to take the Knight...sacrificing my Knight and forcing his King to move away from the pawn
moves.67. Ke7: this was a bad move that almost cost me the game. I should have moved to g6
moves.68. f7: At this point I think I am going to win the game!
moves.68... h3: The secret is to get the queen and then keep the black King in check
moves.69... Kg3: so now my strategy must be to force the King to move and progress my King to the battle when I can to try to mate him before he queens
moves.70... Kh2: this move places him in a pin. I get to advance my King and he tries to force a stalemate
moves.71. Kf6: now 8 points up, I am sure that I will win
moves.71... Kh1: I still have to keep him in check
moves.72... Kg1: Wise to the idea that he needs to advance his pawn, he moves away forcing me to
moves.73. Qd1+: continue to the plan to keep him in check
moves.73... Kg2: I can feel the end game developing and I feel confident that a mate will result
moves.74. Qg4+: now he has a decision to make..keep the  King near the pawn or try to run away
moves.74... Kh2: He chooses to protect his pawn, but this allows me to advance my King
moves.75... Kh1: with this move I should capture his pawn
moves.76. Qxh3+: now the battle is to prevent a stalemate while I advance my King
moves.76... Kg1: he tries to prolong the game
moves.77. Qa3: I ensure that the stalemate is not in the offing
moves.77... Kf1: now I just have to bring my King down and the game is over
moves.78. Qa2: I prevent him from moving out of the first row with this move
moves.78... Ke1: he tries to move into a stalemate
moves.79. Qc2: I try to limit his range to make the checkmate easier
moves.81. Kg4: the end draws near, and with the advance of my King he sees that mate is inevitable so he resigns...a long but interesting game.
